the impact on health and safety, modifications to operating procedures, time period for the change and authorization for the change.  Training of employees must be conducted prior to start-up of the process if the change affects their job task.  In addition, any changes to PSI or operating procedures require these items be updated.  



The purpose of the MOC program is to ensure that modifications to processes are properly evaluated and documented with the same degree of scrutiny as the original process design.  Changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are managed through the MOC process.  Replacements in kind, which are changes to components that are within current design specifications, are not subject to the MOC program.  Procedure changes are managed through a revision process; the other types of changes listed above proceed through the process described below.  Although this document discusses the MOC and PSSR programs separately, these two programs are inextricably linked in practice.  This program is beneficial for release prevention because it provides a process for review of changes and their potential effects prior to their implementation in the process.



Any change that alters the design specification of the process must have a MOC performed.  An MOC is initiated by populating the required information in the MOC system, which includes a description of the change, the justification for the change, the level of scrutiny required for the MOC process and PSSR, the PHA requirements, and training requirements of personnel.  The design basis for the change must be attached.  The MOC may then be reviewed by any or all of the following disciplines:  Health and Safety, Environmental, or Engineering in the areas of process, mechanical, electrical, instrument control, civil, metallurgy, rotating equipment or design engineering (the Health and Safety Review is mandatory).  The MOC has specific sections for personnel in the reviewing discip

lines to identify necessary actions to allow this change to occur.  The actions can fall into any of the following areas:  process technology (PSI is included here), equipment/inspection, rotating equipment, instrumentation/controls, electrical, unit records and procedures/training.  



The Health and Safety Review of the MOC consists of reviewing the areas of industrial hygiene, emergency response, field safety and regulatory compliance.  The industrial hygiene review covers adequacy of PPE and any personnel monitoring, while the emergency response review examines the adequacy of the fire protection equipment and emergency response procedures as they pertain to the change.  Field safety covers adequacy of safety showers, eyewash stations and chemical containment.  Regulatory compliance covers the need for any changes to RMP or Hazardous Materials Business Plan due to the MOC.  A PHA is performed on changes of greater complexity because more scrutiny is required on more complex changes.  The Environmental Department also reviews MOCs with a checklist.  Their checklist examines if the change will increase odors, change air emissions or fugitive emissions, impact effluent water quality, impact groundwater quality, impact any ecological areas, increase hazardous waste generation or require permits.



The MOC is deemed complete when all necessary analysis, work completion, training and document updating has been completed.  Upon completion of the MOC, the Area Supervisor authorizes the completion of the MOC along with the approval of the PHA Coordinator.



Temporary changes are those changes that are expected to exist for a limited period or a change that is being evaluated on a trial basis.  If temporary changes are required, a temporary end date is noted on the MOC form.  At the time of the end of that time, the technical evaluator must confirm that the change has been returned to original conditions, extend the temporary end date, or go through the process to make

the change permanent.  



Employee/Contractor training on the change typically takes place at safety meetings or one-on-one meetings with the supervisor.  In addition, control rooms have MOC binders/log for operators to read as part of the shift change routine.  If changes involve procedures, supervisors are responsible for ensuring that their employees are trained and understand the new procedure.  This may involve one-on-one discussions or practical demonstration.  If PSI updates are required, the marked up PSI is given to the Design Group in Engineering.  The Design personnel then verifies the change prior to changing the PSI.  MOC records are retained for at least 5 years for their use in the revalidation of process PHAs.





Pre Start-up Safety Reviews



Federal, state and local regulations require the performance of a Pre Start-up Safety Review prior to starting any new process or any changes to processes where PSI documents were revised.  The Pre Start-up Safety Review is a confirmation that the construction and equipment was installed according to design specifications, that safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures in place are adequate, any necessary PHAs have been performed, and that employee training has been completed.



The purpose of the Pre Start-up Safety Review (PSSR) program is for Operations to verify that elements required for the operation of new processes or changes to processes have been addressed prior to start-up.  The PSSR examines if the facilities have been engineered and constructed in accordance with the design, operating procedures are complete, personnel responsible for operating and maintaining the process have been appropriately notified or trained and that all applicable documentation is up-to-date and accessible.  Although this document discusses the MOC and PSSR programs separately, these two programs are inextricably linked in practice. The PSSR program is beneficial for accident release prevention because it

provides a process for operations to confirm that a new process or modified process is safe to start.



All new processes and changes to a process that meet MOC criteria must go through the PSSR process.  The PSSR process confirms that all MOC signoffs are complete and that any pre start-up deficiencies have been resolved.  The PSSR process includes:  confirmation that the facilities have been engineered and reviewed per MOC requirements, performance of inspections and tests to verify that construction and installation have been performed according to design specification, confirmation that changes have been communicated to appropriate personnel, confirmation that procedures and other documentation have been prepared and reviewed,  confirmation that any PHA start-up recommendations from the PHA performed for the MOC have been resolved, confirmation that applicable training has been performed and a confirmation that necessary support and emergency response systems are in place.  All new processes and changes to processes must follow the Engineering Standards Manual; inspections and tests are performed for verification.  Redlined copies of P&IDs are placed in the control room prior to start-up.  All operating, maintenance and emergency response procedures changes must be addressed prior to unit start-up.  Employee training on the change typically takes place at safety meetings or one-on-one meetings with the supervisor.  In addition, control rooms have MOC binders/logs for operators to read as part of the shift change routine.  If changes involve procedures, supervisors are responsible for ensuring that their employees are trained and understand the new procedure.  This may involve one-on-one discussions or practical demonstration.  PSSR records are retained with MOC records.  Any recommendations from the MOC/PSSR process are tracked through a database.  The Operations Supervisor verifies the completeness of the PSSR by field walkthrough and inspection and then auth

orizes the start-up.  At this time, new or modified equipment may be started up or placed into service.  



Compliance Audits



Federal, state and local regulations require that employers audit their compliance at least once every three years, at least one knowledgeable person in the process must conduct the audit, and a report must be developed.  A system for tracking the audit findings must be developed and implemented.  These regulations also require that the last two compliance audit reports must be retained.



The purpose of the Compliance Audit Program is to determine the status and effectiveness of the Risk Management Programs established to meet the regulatory requirements of the Process Safety and Risk Management Regulations.  The Compliance Audit program is beneficial to accidental release prevention because the objective of the program is to assess existing Risk Management Programs and to find ways to improve the programs.  



The refinery has conducted Compliance Audits at least every three years since the implementation of OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard.  The two most recent audits were in 2012 and 2015.  Each audit lasted approximately one week and reviewed all of the Risk Management Programs.  The Compliance Audit methodology utilized was a Corporate checklist which is based on the Federal OSHA's Program Quality Verification (PQV) method and also includes OSHA's National Emphasis Program (NEP).  The Corporate checklist also includes the API PSM Assessment.  PQV method consists of evaluating the program, comparing the quality of the program with others in the industry and finally, verifying the implementation of each program.  PQV type audits are accomplished by conducting reviews of records, interviewing employees and conducting field observations.  



Compliance Audit team members are chosen based upon their knowledge and experience.  The final team will have members with knowledge and experience in refinery processing, regulatory req

uirements, and compliance auditing.  The audit team leader has experience both in refinery processes and auditing methodology.  Past audit teams have consisted of a mix of refinery personnel from other sites and personnel from Corporate Headquarters.  The most recent audit also employed outside consultants to conduct the compliance audit.



Findings from the Compliance Audits are written as a final report.  Corrections of the findings are assigned to personnel in pertinent areas; a date for completion of the action is also assigned.  The findings and their corrective actions are tracked in databases maintained by the Health and Safety department.  (This database system also tracks findings from other types of audits and incident investigations.)  Minimally, the last two compliance audits are retained in the filing system.



Incident Investigation



Federal, state and local regulations require the development and implementation of an incident investigation program that addresses investigations for incidents which resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  In addition, local regulations require the conduct of a Root Cause Analysis for all Major Chemical Accidents or Releases.



The refinery has an Incident Investigation program that establishes uniform procedures for reporting and investigating accidents and near misses at the refinery.  An incident is defined as an accident or near miss.  The program focuses on determining the facts surrounding the incident and formulating corrective actions to prevent similar incidents from recurring.  The Incident Investigation program is beneficial to accidental release prevention because corrective actions are generated during investigations to prevent the incident from occurring again.



The Incident Investigation program classifies incidents into three categories, Non-Team (Minor), Small Team (Serious) and Large Team (Major).  Non-team level incidents are investigated

by an Area Supervisor using a causal factor approach to determine the cause of the incident.  Team level incidents are investigated by multi-disciplinary teams using Root Cause Analysis methodology.  



All employees have some level of responsibility for the Incident Investigation program.  All employees are required to immediately report incidents and contribute all knowledge of the incident and offer suggestions for use in developing corrective actions.  When an accident or near miss occurs, it is logged into the refinery incident investigation tracking system and is assigned an incident number.  Each event is promptly categorized to ensure the correct level of investigation is initiated in a timely manner.  All incident investigations must be commenced within 48 hours of the incident.  An investigation form is then completed that includes the following information:  a classification of the incident, date and time of incident, date and time investigation began, CWS level, incident checklist (e.g. type of injury or release), the location of the incident, facts about the incident, information about involved personnel, any immediate actions taken to mitigate hazards, list of corrective actions, and a witness interview form.  For minor investigations, a causal factor checklist is completed to assist in the development of proper corrective actions.  The causal factor checklist is a guidance form that was developed by the National Safety Council.  



Team level incidents are investigated using Root Cause Analysis methodology.  Root Cause Analysis is an in-depth investigation method that determines the underlying causes of an incident.  The refinery utilizes the root cause mapping method by ABS to perform Root Cause Analysis.  This method is based upon a method developed by the Department of Energy.  The investigation involves gathering data by performing site inspections, conducting interviews of involved personnel and emergency responders and reviewing relevant docu

mentation, such as regulations, standards, engineering data and refinery procedures.  This data is then analyzed by placing the information into a logic flow type diagram to determine the root causes.  The final report from a Root Cause Analysis includes the same incident investigation form as described above as well as a more comprehensive report about the findings from the incident.  The report will describe:  the location of the incident and equipment involved, date and time of incident, date and time investigation began, description of events leading to incident, description of conditions existing at the site prior to incident, description of how and why incident occurred based on findings, description of emergency response, causal factors and root causes identified, description of the nature and severity of losses suffered and a statement about specificity of incident to this or other processes.



Team level incident investigations are conducted by teams.  Every team must have a member knowledgeable in Root Cause Analysis methodology.  (The refinery has a number of employees that have taken an incident investigation class covering Root Cause Analysis methodology.)  Every team must also have an employee knowledgeable in the process involved.  The team leader is appointed by the Incident Steward.  Incident Stewards are the Area Superintendent/Manager for minor and serious level investigations and Department Managers for major investigations.   The team leader is responsible for the overall investigation, including recommendations, and signing the final report.  The Investigation Steward is responsible for authorizing the corrective actions.  Serious level incidents require a minimum team size of two members, but must be larger if the nature of the incident requires more expertise on the team.  Team members may be selected from First and Second Line Supervision, Maintenance, Engineering or other technical experts, and the Health and Safety Department.  Major leve

l incidents require a minimum team size of five members, but must be larger if the nature of the incident requires more expertise on the team.  Team members may be selected from Department Superintendents, First and Second Line Supervision, Maintenance, Engineering or other technical experts, and the Health and Safety Department.



Once an incident investigation is completed, the incident investigation form and corrective actions are entered into the incident investigation tracking system.  Each corrective action is assigned to a responsible employee along with a completion date.  Incident Investigations are required to be retained minimally for five years, although refinery records extend back farther than this date.  Upon completion of the incident investigation, the findings are shared with employees through weekly/monthly safety meetings, daily notes, safety bulletins and/or other communication methods as appropriate.  Results of incident investigations meeting reporting requirements are shared with the County through filing of 72 hour and 30 day reports as well as a final Root Cause Analysis Report.  Root Causes of accidents falling under the purview of Ordinance 98-48 will be discussed under the Accident History section.  Results of incident investigations are shared with other stationary sources through Contra Costa Community Awareness Emergency Response (CAER) and through the Western States Petroleum Association.  Results are shared with the public through reports to the County.  



Hot Work



Federal, state and local regulations require the development and implementation of a written procedure for issuance of hot work permits.  The permits are required to certify that certain portions of the fire prevention and protection regulations have been implemented prior to beginning any hot work.  Hot work is defined as any work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing or similar spark-producing operations.



The refinery has a written permitting prog

ram to address Hot Work.  The purpose of the Hot Work program is to develop and implement consistent hot work practices and precautions to control tasks that may create sources that could potentially ignite.  The program also provides consistent planning and authorization of those tasks.  The Hot Work program is beneficial to accidental release prevention because it provides a consistent methodology to address prevention of fires that could potentially result from ignition producing work.  In addition, the Hot Work program satisfies the requirements of the CalARP regulation and Title 8 California Code of Regulations Sections 4848 and 6777.



The Hot Work Permitting Program applies to all equipment or tasks capable of generating energy sufficient to ignite flammable/combustible materials, vapors or gasses.  The equipment and tasks are divided into two categories, high energy and low energy.  Some of the activities qualifying as low energy include the use of battery operated tools, grinding, chipping concrete and flash photography.  Some of the high energy tasks are gas or electric welding, pre or post weld heat treating, and abrasive blasting on storage tanks.  Whenever practical, employees and contractors are to move the job requiring Hot Work to the shop or weld bay to avoid performing this work in the process area.



Prior to each Hot Work job, a permit must be completed.  The permit requires the following information to be filled out:  the date and time of job start, equipment identification, the type of work to be performed, classification of the hot work as low or high energy, a checklist for site preparation, a checklist for any PPE requirements, a checklist for emergency provisions, and atmospheric testing results.  All permits require the performance of atmospheric tests for percent oxygen and percent hydrocarbon; the time of the test performance must be clearly documented.  Other types of atmospheric tests may also be required depending upon the nature of

the work and process area.  The refinery has a work classification table that addresses the risk assessment for various tasks, including the hot work levels.  The work classification table specifies the potential hazards, protective measures required, and also specifies who is required to review and sign the permit.  These signatures mean that the permit has been reviewed, the proper tests have been performed and that the job site is safe to allow work to proceed.  If additional personnel are required for the job, each of them must also review and sign the permit.  Upon completion of the job, the responsible operator and the craftsperson review the site to ensure that it has been left clean and in a safe condition.  Once the Hot Work is complete, copies of the permits are retained for two years.



Hot Work permits are good from the start time listed on the permit until the ending time listed on the permit.  At each shift change, the operator coming on shift reviews the permit, reviews the work site, conducts or verifies atmospheric testing and documents their findings on the permit or the hot work atmospheric test results card.  If conditions, precautions, work scope, or work procedures change, the Hot Work permit is terminated and a new permit must be issued.  One of the ways to monitor the conditions is with the atmospheric testing required in the Hot Work permit.  In addition, if there is an emergency anywhere in the refinery, all Hot Work must be terminated.  



The fire watch is responsible for monitoring the condition of the job site during the performance of Hot Work.  The fire watch wears an identifying vest, has a fire extinguisher or charged hose, a radio for communication purposes and an air horn to alert personnel to stop work.  The fire watch must be trained in the use of the type of fire extinguisher required for the job.  Fire watches remain at the job site for 30 minutes after the Hot Work is completed.



The Hot Work instructions are available o

n the refinery intranet for all employees.  In addition, hard copies of the instructions and permits are available in Health and Safety.  Hot Work Permits are continuously audited by the Health and Safety Department as part of the safe work practices audit.  The results of this Permit Compliance Audit are analyzed for common trends.  The Field Safety Superintendent manages all changes to the Hot Work instructions and permits.  Employee involvement on development and maintenance of the Hot Work instructions and permits occurs through the Joint Health and Safety Committee.  Employees are informed of changes through the weekly/monthly safety meetings and email distribution.



Contractors



Federal, state and local regulations address requirements for the Contractor program by placing requirements on the employer and on the contractor (the employer of the contractor employees).  The regulations require the employer to: 

    inform the contractor about process hazards, 

    explain the applicable emergency action plan provisions to the contractor, 

    evaluate the contractor safety program prior to their hire, 

    periodically evaluate the hired contractor's safety program, 

    maintain an injury/illness log of the contractor's work in process areas and 

    have a safe work practices program that controls the entrance, presence and exit of contractor employees to process areas.  



The Contractor is required to:  

    assure their employees are trained in safe work practices necessary for the job, 

    assure each employee understands the process hazards and applicable parts of the employer's emergency action plan, 

    document that each contractor employee has received and understood this required training,

    assure that their employees follow the facility's safety rules and 

    advises the employer of any unique hazards presented by the contractor work or found during the contract work.



The

refinery, as the employer, has a Contractor program with the objective of hiring competent and knowledgeable contractor employees to perform work safely on refinery processes.  This program applies to all Contractor employees working in process areas.  The Contractor program is beneficial to accidental release prevention because it ensures that contract employees are trained in and practice safe work practices.



Contractors must pass a qualification process prior to hire.  The refinery currently has a third party managing the contractor qualification process.  First, the Contractor must complete a pre-qualification package that covers their Worker's Compensation Experience Modification Rate, OSHA 300 Log, compliance with Title 8 CCR Section 3202 (Injury and Illness Prevention Program), drug and alcohol testing program, employee training programs, and Process Safety Programs.  The Contractor then must provide documentation about these programs during an interview process.  After hire, the Contractor's compliance with Process Safety Management (PSM) and their safety performance at the refinery is periodically audited depending upon the length of the contract.  In addition, the Field Safety Superintendent maintains a safety record for the contractor employees during their employment at the refinery.  These records are kept a minimum of three years.  Contractors must re-qualify every three years.



Although it is the Contractor's responsibility to train their employees in the process hazards and emergency action plan and to document that training, the refinery requires all contract employees annually attend a safety orientation specific to the refinery.  This class covers refinery safety procedures, safe work practices, PPE, the permitting program, the meaning of the refinery alarms, the evacuation routes and evacuation gathering locations.  Written exams are administered at the conclusion of the orientation.  Minimally, the attendance records and exams are kept on

file for one year.



In addition, all contractor employees working in process areas must complete an Occupational Safety Council of America (OSCA) class, a Refinery Safety Overview (RSO) class or an approved equivalent prior to entering the refinery.  Approved courses include several areas of worker safety.  These subjects included are:  Cal-OSHA, Process Safety Management (PSM), refinery equipment and refinery processes, job hazard analyses, personal protection practices (including respiratory protection, hearing and eye protection, head, hand and foot protection and fall protection), Hazard Communication (including how to read a SDS and material labeling), Safe work permits (such as lock-out/tag-out, confined space entry, hole watch procedures for confined space), electrical hazards, elevated work on ladders and scaffolds, Hot Work permitting (including fire watch procedures, and proper use of a fire extinguisher) and alcohol and substance abuse and testing.  The contractor employees must pass a test on these materials prior to completion of the class.  



The control of contractors' access to the facility is managed through Refinery Security.  Once a Contractor has been hired to work at the refinery, they must submit a list of active employees to Refinery Security.  Each contractor employee receives a vehicle placard, which allows them to drive to contractor parking lots.  Contractor employees must badge-in with the guard at the gate prior to entering the refinery.  



The control of contractors to process areas is managed as part of the safe work practices as discussed under Operating Procedures.  Operators control all non-operator access to the process area.  All personnel, including contractor and refinery employees, who are not operators, must report to the control room or other designated area before entering the process area.  The operator reviews the task to be performed with the non-operator employee.  If the task is simple, such as a visual examinatio

n of some process equipment, the operator may issue a permit that simply requires the non-operator employee to sign-in and sign-out at the control room or other designated area.  However, if the task is more involved, it requires pre-planning with the operators and preparation of the appropriate safe work permits (such as Hot Work, Confined Space, Safe Work, etc.)  There are no exceptions.



As part of Federal, State and local regulations, Contractors are required to notify the refinery of any hazards presented by their work or found during their work.  Prior to performance of any tasks, contractor employees fill out a checklist (a job hazard analysis) from the Contractor employer that covers performance of the safe work practices covered by the permitting program.  This checklist is kept with the permitting package during the performance of the work.  In addition, the refinery's Eagle Eye program for reporting unsafe situations/conditions includes contractors.  This allows for contractors to communicate information about hazards to refinery personnel.  The refinery also has a Contractor Action Safety Committee that provides safety leadership to contractors.  This group meets monthly and discusses safety topics.  The group also conducts monthly permit compliance audits on contractors working on process units.





Five-Year Accident History



The RMP and CalARP regulations require a listing of accidents occurring over the last five which meet specific criteria listed in the regulation.  



Please refer to the data fields in the RMP for the Accident History.





Emergency Response Program



Federal, state and local regulations require the development and implementation of an emergency response plan that describes emergency preparedness and response and addresses notification of the public.  The emergency response plan is also required to address the use, inspection, testing and maintenance of emergency response equipment and the training of the facility's emerge

ncy response personnel.



The refinery's emergency response program is described in a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and it consists of an emergency response organization, procedures for response and equipment for response.  This program addresses emergency response for fires, explosions, releases of hazardous materials and medical emergencies.  The ERP addresses coordination with local agencies and the public.  The ERP has been prepared in coordination with the local emergency response area plan as required by CalARP, RMP and ISO.  In addition, the ERP contains the Oil Spill Contingency Plan, the Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan and the Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan as annexes.  The refinery's current ERP was issued in May, 2015.  The plan is reviewed on a regular basis to assure that the plan represents the most effective approach for protecting workers, the public and the environment.  It may be revised if any of the following activities indicate the need for a change:  applicable federal, state or local regulatory changes, the ERP fails in an emergency, significant changes in facility operation occurs, the emergency contact list changes, changes occur in emergency response equipment or procedures, or a review reveals a deficiency in the ERP.



Notification:



In the event of a serious fire, explosion, hazardous material release, or medical emergency, employees or contractors call 2222 and report the nature of the emergency to Security Control.  Security Control will then sound emergency alarms (for serious fire, explosion, hazardous material releases only), and make announcements over the refinery radios and the refinery public address system.  The Shift Superintendent activates emergency call-outs.  The refinery-wide horn is sounded for emergencies that require a facility-wide response.  Employees are alerted when this horn sounds four long blasts.  (The refinery-wide horn is actually five horns sounded simultaneously.)  Immediatel

y following the horn, Security Control announces the nature of the emergency over the refinery-wide announcing system.  Security Control also pages the appropriate emergency response groups.  For emergencies isolated to a single process unit, the unit horn will sound six short blasts.  Two short blasts on the refinery-wide horn indicate an "All Clear".  The Chemical Plant has supplementary signals in addition to the refinery's signals.  The supplemental signals include one continuous blast indicating an emergency, a series of short blasts indicating the need for evacuation of the plant, a series of "wow-wow-wow" blasts indicating a Hydrogen Sulfide release and a long-short-long blast indicating an "All Clear".  



The emergency action plan requirements are included in the Emergency Response Plan.  It describes employee actions for the evacuation of process areas.  If any of the emergency alerts are sounded, workers have been instructed to immediately stop work, shut down any ignition sources, and proceed to a designated employee gathering area.  Emergencies requiring employee evacuation will have an evacuation announcement immediately following the alert.  Employees then proceed to designated evacuation areas where they are counted.  All employees receive initial training on emergency actions via a safety orientation when they are hired.  In addition, every year employees receive refresher training on this subject; it is covered in an annual CBT training and an annual safety class.  All Contractor employees receive initial training and annual refresher training in this area as well.  The emergency alarms for employees are regularly tested.  The refinery-wide horn is formally tested with four blasts on the first Wednesday of the month at 11:00 AM, concurrently with the Community Warning System (CWS) sirens.  In addition, testing of the paging system occurs every Monday at 7 PM.



Depending upon the nature of the emergency, the Shift Superintendent (the Initial Inci

dent Commander) will immediately activate the Community Warning System (CWS).  The activation of the CWS for a Level 3 event will sound sirens, activate the County's phone system, and send preprogrammed advisories to the news media and regulatory agencies.  The CWS Sirens are used to alert the public to an event at the refinery for which Shelter-In-Place is recommended; the public should listen to TV and radio broadcasts for further instructions.  The refinery has four Telephone Emergency Notification System (TENS) zones for calling local residences and businesses.  When activated, the TENS phone system will call residents and businesses in the specified TENS zone with a recorded message about the event and how to Shelter-In-Place.  The TENS zones are shown in Appendix C.  



The Initial Emergency Operations Center (EOC) Commander is the Shift Superintendent and he is responsible for immediately notifying the following agencies:  Contra Costa Health Services (CCHS), Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD), Contra Costa County Office of Emergency Services (CCCOES), and the Contra Costa Fire District about the emergency.  As part of that notification, the Initial EOC Commander will inform the agencies about the CWS level established for the emergency.  Additional agency notifications by facility personnel may be made depending upon the nature of the emergency to the following agencies:  Cal-OSHA, California Department of Fish and Game, California Highway Patrol, Concord Police Department, Contra Costa County Sheriff, Department of Toxic Substances Control, Martinez Police Department, National Response Center, Regional Water Quality Control Board, State Fire Marshall, State Lands Commission, State Office of Emergency Services, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. EPA, and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.



If ambulance transport is required during the emergency, Security Control will call American Medical Response (AMR) or an Air Ambulance Service, CalSTAR or REACH.  Secu

rity Control has the direct phone numbers for these organizations.  Upon arrival of the ambulance, the paramedics will be given an informational package, which includes a copy of the SDS if the transported person was exposed to any chemicals.  An employee will accompany the transported person to the hospital.  



Organization and Response:



The refinery has implemented an Incident Command System (ICS) to ensure effective, well-organized and adequately staffed emergency responses utilizing the emergency response teams and emergency response equipment.  Initially in an emergency, the Shift Superintendent assumes control as the initial EOC Commander.  Site control is established to limit access to the area involved in the emergency by the onsite initial Incident Commander (IC).  The onsite initial IC is one of the operations Shift Supervisors.  The initial IC is responsible for the actual emergency response in the field.  The emergency response personnel respond to and actively mitigate the emergency situation to bring it under control.  Depending upon the nature and extent of the emergency, the Incident Commander may require support from the Emergency Operation Center (EOC).  The EOC is staffed with supervisory personnel to fill the following positions as needed for the emergency:  Incident Commander, Safety Officer, Information Officer, Liaison Officer, Legal Affairs Officer, Operations Section, Planning Section, Logistics Section and Finance Section.  The role of these personnel is to provide support to the emergency response personnel in the field and address concerns in portions of the refinery that are not involved in the emergency, interface with agency personnel and address any community concerns.  



The emergency responders are organized, trained, and capable of responding to fires, explosions, hazardous material releases, emergency medical situations and rescues.  There are two principal emergency response teams at the refinery, the Fire Brigade and the

Oil Spill Response Team.  Subteams of the Fire Brigade makeup the HazMat team, EMT team and Rescue team.  Initial training of Fire Brigade members includes a 40-hour classroom training course.  The 40-hour course covers basic fire-fighting principles, ICS, proper protective equipment including use of a Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA), safety, teamwork, communication, basic hose handling, rescue training, water management and use of effective streams, emergency response vehicles, industrial fire fighting, structure/building emergencies and fire/rescue in a flare area.  In addition, every year, members of the Fire Brigade attend a two day long industrial fire-fighting course at a facility with live-fire capability.  Course attendees also practice putting out industrial fires on training structures.  In addition, the fire brigade conducts three hours of refresher training every month at the refinery.  The training can be one of twenty training modules, including topics such as protective equipment, behavior of fire, fire system pumps, hose handling, SCBA, CPR, First Aid, Foam, Wildland Fire Fighting, HazMat and Rescue.  For the Fire School Class and the monthly training modules, Fire Brigade members demonstrate competency by both written and practical exams.  In addition to the Fire Brigade training, HazMat team members receive additional training, including a 40-hour HAZWOPER class and additional monthly training specific to their area.  The EMTs are certified through a State program and attend bi-monthly training as required by the State certification program.  In addition to the Fire Brigade training, the Rescue team members receive an eighty hour class on rescue training and have additional monthly training specific to their area.  



The emergency response teams have a variety of emergency response equipment to use in responding to an emergency.  Fixed fire protection systems are located throughout the refinery and consist of dedicated pumps and water s

upplies, water cannons (monitors), and deluge/spray systems.  Some of the mobile fire fighting equipment available includes:  two fire engines capable of pumping water and foam, a truck with aerial pumping capability, a brush fire pumper, one "super-pumper" capable of pumping larger volumes of foam and water, several portable monitors, a "quick attack" vehicle, a trailer with additional SCBA units and a HazMat trailer with protective equipment including Level A suits.  In addition, all process areas have eye wash stations, safety showers, fire extinguishers, SCBAs, first aid kits and blankets.  Emergency response equipment is inspected and tested monthly by the Fire Marshals.  Fire truck pumps and stationary pumps are performance tested annually for flow rates.  



Permanent gas detectors for Hydrogen Sulfide and Ammonia are located in the relevant process areas.  For example, there is an ammonia detector at the Chemical Plant near the ammonia storage area.  Permanent hydrocarbon gas detectors are also located in applicable areas of the refinery.  In addition, there are Ground Level Monitors (GLMs), required by BAAQMD, for Hydrogen Sulfide and Sulfur Dioxide.  There are three monitors for each chemical in four different potential downwind locations.  In addition, during an emergency, the refinery can dispatch personnel to perform real time monitoring of the community for any of the following:  Hydrogen Sulfide, Ammonia, Sulfuric Acid, Sulfur Dioxide, respirable size particulate matter, and total hydrocarbon concentration.  Refinery personnel may also use summa canisters to collect airborne samples if desired.  The refinery may also dispatch the Odor Science and Engineering Contractor to determine if any odors are occurring offsite.



Coordination



The refinery is an active member of CAER.  CAER is a nonprofit group comprised of industry, agency and community members that are dedicated to a safe and informed public.  CAER's core objectives are safe industrial fac

ility operations, coordinated emergency response, providing an effective safety sharing forum and development of a trust-based relationship with the community.  CAER has several committees under its charter to accomplish these objectives.  The committees are:  personal safety, process safety, community outreach, emergency notification, emergency response preparedness and drill coordination, Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization, and Industrial Hygiene.  Refinery personnel participate in all of the committees.



As part of CAER, the refinery participated in the development of the Community Warning System, a system to alert and inform the public about accidental releases of hazardous material.  Refinery personnel participated in the initial CWS education of the public about the CWS and Shelter-in-Place.  The refinery continues to be an active partner in the use of the CWS in order to provide early notification to neighboring communities about incidents that have the potential for offsite impacts.  



The refinery is a member of CAER's Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization (PMAO) committee.  PMAO is an organization of industrial facilities and public agencies that focus on mutual aid response to emergencies.  The members of PMAO provide assistance (material and equipment) to any member requiring aid during an emergency situation.  The refinery may request assistance from PMAO during an emergency or refinery personnel may be part of a response at another facility as part of PMAO.  Some of the PMAO membership includes:  Tesoro, ConocoPhillips, DOW Chemical, Chevron, Valero, Shell, and Rhodia.  Agencies, including Contra Costa Health Services (CCHS), Rodeo/Hercules Fire Department, Contra Costa Emergency Medical Services (EMS), Contra Costa Fire Protection District, American Medical Response (AMR), U.S. Coast Guard, and the Richmond Fire Department, also attend PMAO meetings.  PMAO is dispatched through the Chevron Refinery Fire Department or DOW Chemical.  





Planne

d Changes to Improve Safety





The Refinery continues to upgrade the refinery with planned changes to improve safety.  The projects selected for inclusion on this list provide significant reduction in the potential for catastrophic releases due to design changes, inventory reduction, equipment replacement and/or the project provides increased capability to respond to a catastrophic event.



Continuing upgrades to the Refinery Infrastructure.  As part of a project to improve refinery infrastructure, old refinery tankage and pipeways are being removed/upgraded.  New tanks and pipeways will be constructed to replace some of the old equipment.  However, there will be a net reduction in storage capacity at the refinery.  [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]



Seismic Study.  Seismic assessments are performed for the following units every 5 years:  the Ammonia Recovery Unit, the Acid Plant, #3 HDS, the Refrigerated Butane Storage Tanks, the Butane Storage Spheres, the DEA Stripper, the FCCU/4Gas complex, the Coker(DCU)/5Gas complex, Hydrocracker Stage 1/Stage 2/Hydrogen plant complex, #2 HDS, LPG storage, the Alky Plant and the Sulfur Recovery Unit (SRU).  Recommendations from these assessments are tracked to completion. [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]



Facility Siting Study.  The refinery had a comprehensive Facility Siting Study performed on inhabited buildings throughout the refinery.  The study identified facility siting issues for the refinery.  A number of portable buildings have been relocated our of the process area.  Further action is currently under study by the Engineering Department to determine recommendations for the remaining identified issues.  For a more detailed discussion of the facility siting study, please refer to the Process Hazard Analysis section.  [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]



Refinery Safety Instrumented System (SIS) Upgrades.  Each SIS has been reviewed to evaluate the performance required.  Ongoing ana

lyses find and correct any identified performance gaps.  [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]



Wharf upgrades.  Seismic upgrades to both refinery wharves have been completed that allow them to withstand a severe seismic event.  In addition, lighting, fire water systems and back up power systems have been upgraded.
